Pours a dark, almost cola color - almost opaque, semi-translucent with a small off-white head. Aroma was sweet brown sugar, dried fruits, lots of malt, and booze. Flavor was sweet malts, sugar, brown sugar. Booze. Very warming, but a little much for me, even in just a small quantity.

Pours dark brown with low off white head
Aromas of butterscotch, raisins, port, figs, brown sugar, bourbon
Taste is perfectly balanced with great tones of figs, dades, brown sugar, vanilla, wood, burned caramel. Great!

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2014 Pours a deep ruby/caramel with a thin, ring head. Aroma has a super smooth bourbon, dark fruits, a hint of alcohol, and a touch of chocolate. Taste is sweeter but awesome. Bourbon, dark fruits, hints of roasted malts, and mild alcohol. Full body with a low-medium carbonation. Smooth/syrupy in the mouth with a mild carbonation and a dry finish. Overall an awesome beer. Great, smooth bourbon, dark fruits, and a hint of sweetness.

Draft at Bistro on Bridge. Pours very dark brown to black with little head. Nose is sweet with notes of shoe fly pie, shot of bourbon and a cigar all at once. Flavors are similar with leather and esters. Finish is smooth with mild smoke and sweet molasses. Great stuff.

On tap at Flavor in Half Moon Bay, CA. Pours a thick brown sauce. Aroma is caramel, vanilla, rich malts. Taste is sticky SWEET malts, vanilla, molasses, some oak and burn on the finish. Reminded me quite a bit of The Bruery Smoking Wood (which is also intensely sweet). Probably would enjoy with a cigar.
On draft at Snallygaster 2014 in D.C. Pours a clear dark cola with an ecru head. Roasted malt nose. Flavors of caramel, oak and vanilla. Bitter roast finish.
On tp In dc iritis. Dark brown with. Slight hes the rom is rostedcoffee the taste is lovely smooth bourbon coffee yummy.

This beer pours a very opaque brown color--so much so that no light penetrates through even shallow pours--and there is no head, only the smallest of light tan rings around the edge. The aroma blends molasses, brown sugar, oak, roasted malts, fig raisin, caramel malts, and a hint of malts; the taste is such an indulgence due to the high sweetness blended well with a mild umami, slight sourness, and a touch of booze flavor, the final of which continues and warms through the finish with a hearty malt flavor alongside it. The palate fuses a oily texture, medium-full body, and a nearly flat carbonation that dances alongside the alcohol warmth, and the mouthfeel only enhances the flavors this beer brings.

650 ml bottle. 2014 vintage. Pours a dark brown with very light head. Aromas of vanilla, oak, brown sugar,and dark stewed fruit. Flavors of brown sugar, raisins, light molasses, light bourbon, and sweet malts. Overall quite sweet but big and warm. Expecting something much harsher for the young age. Impressive.
Bottle at end of History tasting. nose is sweet bourbon and vanilla. tastes of lots of vanilla, bourbon sweetness, caramel, coconut, and molasses. very tasty and creamy texture
Bottle shared by Jester Deal at End of History tasting. Pours dark brown. Nose/taste of caramel, brown sugar, dark fruit, bourbon, toffee and oak. Some molasses. Full bodied.
Bottle. Black pour with tan head. Roasted and barrel aged tones, sweet and other malty aromas. Sweet vanilla, oak and whiskey tones, touch of booze but not overwhelming.
At jtclockworks. The aroma is fruit, bourbon, bread. The appearance is deep brown, thin head. The flavor is toffee, fruit, bread, candi, bourbon. Thick, creamy body. Absolutely beautiful.

Catching up on RBAG 2014 notes backlog...I think Ferris shared this bottle. Dark brown with a thick golden head. Beautiful chocolatey Christmas cake aroma. Densely flavoured palate full of rich dark malts, sweet but not cloying, warming but not harsh. Firestone Walker does it again!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle: Thanks, Doug. Super deep brown & ruby body without much head formating taking place, aside from a slightly bubbly, ecru-colored collar around the edge. Sticky sweet aroma of dark plums, prunes, & figs lacquered in a bath of boozy caramel, bourbon, melted brown sugar, molasses, toffee. etc... More like a barley wine or old ale than a quad, it seems. A little black cherry & vanilla, too. Wow, now THATS sweet. Insanely sweet out of the gate. Tons of residual sweetness & unfermented malt sugars. Liquid brown sugar, caramel, & toffee coating an array of dark fruits; dates, plums, figs, cherry, a little bit of grape, even. Displaying the "brighter" side of the "dark" fruits. Heavy undertones of bourbon, barrel induced vanillin, very light coconut & anise, & just a tiny sprinkle of coca dust. Lives up to the namesake thanks to the sticky sweet, Bit O Honey mouth feel. Its a big beer. Its a complex beer. Its definitely good. But a little too over the top sweet to be called "great" (or enjoyed in quantities larger than 6 oz).

Pungent orange, orange peel and grapefruit with a finish that is musty and with yeast. Some caramel, malt and a little bread crust. Thick and sticky. Sweet. Maybe some fruit and coconut but none of the leather and tobacco come through this one. Definitely boozy and bourbony.

Bottle - 2014 vintage. Opaque, murky dark brown with a short tan head. Aroma is slightly boozy with toasted coconut, vanilla notes, sweet malt, caramel, toffee, faint tobacco, dark fruit and molasses. Taste is big coconut and vanilla with molasses, dark fruit, candi sugar, brown sugar, caramel, sweet malt, soft oak and hints of tobacco. Body is medium-full with a strong, bubbly carbonation and sugary stickiness. Soft warmth to this as well. Ends with more boozy notes, vanilla, molasses, caramel, sweet malt, toasted malt, oak and dark fruit. Delicious!

On tap at Harrys Hofbrau. Pours a deep amber, clear with an off-white head. Much like a barley wine, this beer is very sweet and viscous. Overt Belgian candi-sugar and rich and complex flavors throughout.
Bottle cracked with some brahs at Ryans, pours dark red-brown with notes of plum, sticky pudding, vanilla, caramel sugar and oak, Fuller bodied with medium heat and plenty stickiness.

Bottle few months. pours clear brown no head. Aroma is Bourbon caramel light coffee green raisins. Flavor is sweet major and Bourbon fruity sweetness with striking bitterness and bite that balances it out. Wood char and sour mash come through and a bread yeast just peeks through. Feel is surprisingly dry and textured after what starts out with the potential of silk. Really intense but not overpowering. Love it.

Bottle. Dang, this is good, 13+% aint usually my scene, but this bangs. Pours deep brown with head thats almost yellow. Fig, raisin, molasses, brown sugar, vanilla, slight bourbon nose. More too, its nicely complex and layered. Taste is exceptionally balanced for a strong ale -- booze present but kept in check, sweet but not overly so. Did I mention vanilla? It bears repeating. One of the most drinkable strong ales Ive had, a real treat.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with off-white head. Aroma is very strong of figs, raisins, molasses, brown sugar, belgiany, vanilla- lots of aromatics. Tastes is medium to full bodied- coconut, vanilla, sweet, rich, medium carbonation. Very good.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Beer Market Jaffa. Thanks zvikar. Black with frothy beige head. Caramel, earth, a little marzipan aroma. Very sweet, coconut and a little roasty in the mouth. Oily texture, heavy body, no carbonation, long, sweet finish.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2014 Not sure of the evolution of this beer, how it evolved from a tasty slightly oversweet barleywine, to an even more tasty, slightly oversweet "central coast" quad, but its bottled...and thats a good thing. Belgian yeast and candi sugar are present under all that barrel-aged goodness. Very fruity, with brandy and bourbon coming through in the nose and on the palate. Sticky as suggested, though not hot coming in at 13%+. Really enjoyed this. Not quite up there with Abacus and Parabola, but not far off, either

(Draft at Brookland Pint in DC) Dark brown body with a thin tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, molasses, bourbon. Medium to full body. Flavor is sweet, dark fruit, vanilla, strong alcohol; slight tartness, cough syrup.

Bottle. Dark amber-brown beer with a tan head. Sweet malt and dried fruit aroma with light yeast. Rich malt and dried fruit flavor with light yest and light red fruit. Fuller bodied. Caramel and dried fruit linger with light yeast and light plum.
Bomber. Dark brown with moderate beige head. Molasses, toffee, dark fruit, spices. Bit syrupy. Complex and good.

Dradt at Good Dog. Very dark brown pour with a lasting white ring. Sugary burnt caramel. Strong bourbon top notes. Rich dark red stone fruit. Mulling spices. Thick syrupy molasses. Dark vegetation. Plum pudding. Black cherry cordials. Bittersweet and strong. Similar to Belgium Noels but much more powerful. Wonderful stuff!!!

Bottle thanks to Santa! Pours a clear really deep amber with a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has sweet grains and molasses with a touch of toffee bourbon and booze. Flavor has more toffee with some dark grain, coconut, a touch of caramel and bourbon backing.

22 oz bottle. Dark brown with beige froth. Nose is raisin, caramel and porcinis. Big and chewy almost full body with a buzz. Taste is dates, caramel, smoky banana and raisin with hints of spiced rum. Needs some aging to soften the sharp edges but still an impressive American quad. Fat.

Bottle. Pours clear reddish mahogany, small diminishing brown head, some lacing.aroma is bourbon forward, dark sugars, vanilla, oak, cocoa, raisin. Flavor is medium sweet, little bitterness, lots of bourbon and vanilla over toffee, raisin and a bit of quad spiciness. Bourbon is clearly forward here, but not too overpowering. A bit of zesty bitterness on the finish. Medium body, tongue coating. Nice.

Draft. Clear dark mahogany. Small wispy beige head and ring around glass that dissipates. Big sugary caramely sweet sticky aroma bursts from glass. Flavor does the same. Rich sugar and caramel, molasses. Vanilla, tobacco and oak. Bourbon. Some dark fruit. Rich. Decadent. Bigger medium body. Kinda slick. Not that sticky. Light roasty bitterness. Alcohol is there but doesnt detract or get in the way. Delicious barrel character. Excellent dessert sipper but also quite easy to drink. Everything here works so well.

Pours a deep reddish black color with a tan head.Bourbon, oak, molasses, vanilla, soy sauce, roasted malt, caramel, tobacco and dark fruit aroma. Dark fruit, oak, molasses, bourbon, coconut, vanilla, tobacco, caramel and chocolate flavors. Full body and moderate carbonation. Sweet taste and a dark fruit and molasses finish with some bourbon.

Dark ruby brown color, thin beige head. Loads of brown sugar, candied fruits, bourbon soaked oak, sticky caramel, a little leather, and hints of vanilla. Very sweet and viscous. Smooth, full-bodied, and lively with a long bittersweet finish.

Fad: Taster på taproom. Dyb ravfarvet øl med stort skumhoved. Duften er fadlagret men med tydelige gærnoter fra den belgiske gær. Smagen er sød, men lækker og balanceret fra spritten og fadlagringen. Lækker øl.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Beer Market, Jaffa. Thanks zvikar. Clear dark brown. Aroma is woody, vanilla, date honey, biscuit, alcoholic, sweet. Complex flavor of coconut, vanilla, very sweet, cherry, dark fruits. Very alcoholic. Low carbonation. Full body. Sticky sweet aftertaste.
Is this a quad? At its heart yes. Through and through. Thick, dark and syrupy, sweet, slight alcohol burn. Would not be out of place in a Belgian bistro....

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2014 Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks zvikar. Clear brown with a beige head. Aroma of wood, port, spices and caramel. Sweet with coconut, dried fruits, oak, caramel and vanilla flavors, a bit heavy and boozy, but balanced. Medium-full bodied, oily mouthfeel. Good.

2014 Bottle.
Appearance: When not held to light the body appears to be a deep chestnut, though when held to the light the body shows a beautiful deep garnet hue. A short, but quickly disappearing, light tan head appears on the pour, but all thats left is a bubbly ring after a moment.
Aroma: The aroma leans fruity with plums, fig and raisin, followed by deep caramel aromas, some brown sugar, hints of booze, and a dash of leather. The aroma is mellow, though showing off its contents with ease.
Taste: Big dark fruits in the way of plum, raisin, and fig are noticed throughout as are big malts giving flavors of caramel and brown sugar. Bourbon is noticed mostly during the finish with a dash of leather and tobacco. The malts really rise up just before the bourbon hits to push aside the fruity intro a bit. This is a great sipper, full flavored and enjoyable, complex and inviting. The booze is hidden far too well in this, its present but its noticed mildly on the finish.
Palate: Full-bodied, bordering on thick, with light carbonation.
Overall: I find this to be a beer brewed to high standards. Firestone Walker rarely disappoints and this is another winner. Big in flavor while remaining soft and hiding its alcohol far too well, this could be dangerous!

2014 650 ML bottle. Darker pour with a minimal head. Nose is sweet, syrupy, no roast or hoppy notes. Initial flavor is very sweet and sugary, with a smooth body. Similar to a milder barley wine but I can see how this would be a great blend beer with the inherent sweetness.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Bottle sample at a tasting at Beer Market Jaffa. Thanks zvikar. 2014 bottle. Dark brown with amber hues and a beige head. Aroma of dark fruits, caramel, cookies, vanilla, wood, nuts, coconut and a bit of chocolate. Sweet flavor with caramel, dark fruits, vanilla, coconut, some chocolate notes and a spicy boozy edge. Full-bodied, a bit syrupy. A bit too heavy, but very nice.

5oz sample on tap at BJs in Woodland. Aroma has some sweet bourbon woody notes with light vanilla. Some chocolate is also there. Very quaffable. Slightly transparent mahogany body with a medium tan head and good lacing. Starts with a largely sweet bourbon flavor. More sweet woodiness in the middle with chocolate and vanilla. Ethanol is well hidden. Finishes with a chocolate sweetness. Very dangerous. Very drinkable.

On tap at Tribes Alehouse. Pour is dark brown/ruby with a small tan head. Aroma and flavor of bourbon, dark fruit, sweet caramel, toffee, brown sugar, and oak. Finish is sweet and boozy with some added notes of leather and molasses.

Bottle from Lectvay, thanks again! Dark brown pour with ruby tones and a brown head. Aromas of oak, dates, brown sugar, bourbon, and figs. Wow this smells epic. Flavor is sweet dark fruits with bourbon and oak. Finish is a little warm from the abv but I bet cellaring this one for a year or two would mellow it out nicely. Very complex and delicious. Firestone doesnt make a bad beer.

Tap at Maxs. Pours clear black with ruby highlights and a small, fizzy beige head, short retention with spare lacing. Aroma is caramel and brown sugar, dates, figs and prunes with cookie malt and spicy alcohol. Flavor is sweet, nearly cloying, malt with dark candied fruits, brown sugar, molasses, light hops and bitterness and a sweet finish. Full body and light carbonation.

Bottle shared by David. Thanks brother! This was a nice surprise in a style I rarely enjoy much these days. This beer is big and sweet, usually things I hate, but this particular gem is super complex and well put together so the sweetness and booziness do not dictate the beer. Tons of caramelized sugar, light vanilla, cream, very creme brulet like at times. Also get notes of banana split. Light coconut cream, oak, coffee cake. Yummers. One of the best flavors Ive had in a beer in a while. This is a sweet beer I can get into.  Not really a quad at all, but I dont give a shit.

2014 vintage. 22 oz bomber into a tulip. Pours a dark red/brown with a some large edging of light khaki foam. Nose is all kinds of dark fruits and bourbon. Raisins, toffee, caramel, vanilla, charred oak, plums, baking spices, and some booze warmth. Taste is similar. Very much like an english barleywine; dark fruits soaked in bourbon and brown sugar. Sweet and spicy with some fusel heat. Very delicious and different enough from Sucaba to stand out. This is much more brown sugar forward. Smooth and coating mouth feel with enough carbonation. Really delicious beer.

Clear dark mohogany pour with small beige bubbles for a head. Aroma of malts, caramel, vanilla , bourbon, ripe fruits and chocolate. Taste of caramel, toffee, brown sugar, vanilla, coconut, black licorice, plums and figs. Full bodied, lower carbonation, alcohol burn until it warmed to room temperature. Long lasting licorice and bourbon aftertaste. Good beer just slightly too chewy and boozy.

Bottle to goblet at RBAG14
Black currant, rye, malt, and caramel. Dark reddish brown with a thin off white head. Taste is vanilla, caramel, and brown sugar.
Dark brown, big Brown sugar and molasses. Very sweet, not cloying at all. Fantastic.
Bottle - Rich caramel, toffee, dark sugars and chocolate notes. Dark caramel with a small beige head. Tastes just like it smells with some coconut and rich sugar notes. Very nice.
Dark brown quad like pour, aroma of brown sugar, toffee, vanilla, oak, malty sweetness Taste is sweet up front, oak, vanilla, rich smooth finish. Very good.

22 oz bottle. Brown with a decent beige head. Aroma is of oak, vanilla, toffee, leather, prune, raisin, light dried cherries, fruit cake, and molasses. Taste is of oak, light chocolate, vanilla, toffee, tobacco, molasses, light rum, tons of dried fruit.

Bottle. The look is dark, dark brown in color, red tinges, and a thin beige head. The smell is tobacco, toffee, sweet, deep, complex, leather, and nice. The taste is tobacco, leather, bourbon, wood, dried fruit, complex, great.

Well godsdamn...lucky enough to get this on tap a week ago at The Bier Stein in Eugene. Big molasses and coconut nose, sweet sugar malts as well. Flavors are rich dark fruit, molasses, hints of coconut husk, and bits of toast. Finish has more sweetness than anything else, but lingers with a beautiful hint of booze. Yummy!

Dark brown with no foam but plenty of carbonation. Excellent variety and depth of character. Vanilla, oak, dark fruits, alcohol, licorice, brown sugar, and more I cant describe. Definitely a Belgian even though its listed as a Strong Ale on this site. Sweet and spicy. Needs a little more time to mellow.

Pour from 750mL bottle. Pours a dark brownish black with very little head. Aroma smells of slight booze, licorice, fruits, vanilla and sugar. Taste is licorice as advertised, some fruit, a TON of vanilla, some booze again. Palate dances between licorice, fruits, sugars, vanilla, booze and more licorice with a nice sugary finish.

This 2014 vintage quad is as advertised. Sweet hints of plums and boysenberry coat the palate. Herbal undertones compliment the sweetness well and balance this beer nicely. Easy drinking for an ale of this abv. Could stand to age a bit more to mellow the sugar smack.

A very nice, but quite intense beer. Pours a beautiful black with a hint of red. Smells boozy, with some bourbon and blackberry jam. Taste is creamy, with some port or sherry, and anise. Lots of sweetness left on the tongue. Had on tap at Hopmonk.

Poured from tap to glass. Dark brown hue with creamy tan head that dissipated to a thick ring. Aroma is caramel, molasses, raisins, banana, prunes, leather, floral esters, ethanol. Mouthfeel is great with a full body and soft carbonation. Taste is sweet throughout with slight astringent following and ethanol finish. Overall this us a great brew!

Pours a dark brown with minimal carb. Smells of burnt sugar, slight bourbon, caramel. Taste is sweet but rounded out by bourbon and cut by the barrel finishes with burnt marshmallow flavor. Excellent beer

651 ml. bottle. Pours a medium, poorly retained, fizzy, beige head over a clear brown (SRM 25) body....nose is heavy dried fruits with plum, raisin, light molasses, tobacco, dust, minimal hops, malts and sugar dominant.....taste is sweet, with brown sugar, light molasses, hints of treacle, dried fruits including raisin, prune, hints of tobacco, cocoanut, light vanilla, barely detectable hop bitterness, balance to the malts and sugars.....mouth feel, body light, but 13.4% ABV will do that, alcohol burn (not fusel) present, sticky (no surprise with all the sugar), carbonation adds light tingle. This is a very, very sweet highly alcoholic (which increases sweetness) beer. It needs long aging time to begin to approach any sort of balance beyond simple sweetness. As it is tasted now, it is too immature to do it justice. They really should have aged it in neutral (glass, steel) containers for a year or two, charged more and had a better outcome. BJCP 9/2/12/4/6

Bottle. Holy schnikey. This is among the richest beers Ive ever had. Thick with licorice, licorice and more licorice. Silky smooth, sweet to a fault, with a big evident alcohol kick. Be careful with an open flame. Wow. (#5567, 7/1/2014)
Dark, dark amber color, moderate head, decent lace/retention. Aroma is vanilla, oak, caramel, sugar, some darker fruit. Full bodied, sticky, sweet. This is not a quad and is correctly categorized.

On tap @ Uber. Pours dark opaque reddish brown with thin lacy cream-colored head. Aroma is huge thick sticky sweet malt... strong notes of hazelnuts, plums, port-soaked raisins, oak, barrel-aged rum... wow. Taste is syrupy sweet oaky malt... solid flavors of fig, oatmeal, toasted caramel. Super boozy, although the big flavors really balance it out. Love that Firestone is bringing the constituent beers of their outstanding anniversary blends to market - this can only be good news.

A- pours a slightly viscous opaque mahogany cola with a medium beige head. Light lacing. S- very rich vanilla, toasted coconut, brown sugar, figs, prunes, raisin bread, rhubarb pie, cherry cordial, ripe apples and light tobacco. And the alcohol....oh the alcohol. M- full and heavy oily, viscous body with a heavy sweet palate. Light carb. T- very sweet and sugary to start. Vanilla once again leads the way with the coconut, rhubarb, molasses and cola. Memories of German chocolate cake. Mid palate is slightly vegetal with tobacco, as well as heavy on the dried fruits, apples and cherries plus bready notes. Ending has a lingering sweetness mixed with sharper hop and mineral flavors. Efficient and relatively clean as well.

Sample at Falling Rock. The beer is a murky reddish-brown color with a medium beige head that diminishes gradually. Patchy lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, dark fruit and vanilla. Full-bodied with flavors of plums, caramel malt, earthy yeast and oaky vanilla. The finish is slightly syrupy with a dark fruit and malt aftertaste. Good beer all around.

On tap at Belmont Station. Good thing; I couldnt take one of these down by myself. #600.

A: Brown with purple hints. No head, and its hard to see carbonation in the mire. 

N: Bourbon, vanilla, caramel, coconut, toffee, malt, tobacco, cola, leather, buttery shortbread cookie. 

T: Very, very sweet. Holy crap sweet. Yet, not totally cloying. 

M: A monkey with a good grip on the palate. Sticky fingers, in other words. Heavy body. 

O: A very tasty beer. It does better as part of the Anniversary blend series, given its intensity, but even on its own, it represents a great beer to share. I wouldnt drink more than a quarter of a bottle by myself, though.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2014 Bottle. Black. Sweet and light sticky roasted malt with a perfect sugary barrel presence. The alcohol is completely hidden. Overall excellent, top notch. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Red wine color with almost no head. Aroma is heavy on barrel, dark fruit, syrup and wood. Taste follows pretty closely. Mouthfeel is slightly thin and buttery but doesn't feel lacking. Like a barrel aged port wine. Delicious.

Sticky body with quickly receding off-white head. No lacing, but some serious legs. Aroma and flavor of toasted coconut, toffee, tobacco, leather, and brown fruits. Very sweet, but not nearly as cloying as the very comparable Bruery Bois. The perfect companion for a beautifully aged cigar like this Dunhill Esplendido.

On tap at Belmont Station. Colour...deep amber-brown with a thin tan head. Nose...steeped brown sugar, turbinado and dark scottish toffee. Palate...ultra sweet and cloying! Like a diabetic coma in a glass!! After the sugared assault, the flavours of treacle, light bodied molasses and butterscotch come through mid palate. The mouthfeel is dry, as well as sweet and theres some burnt sugar bitterness too. The finish is long and sweet and brimming with cinnamon buns and Sugar Babies.
On tap at the Red Hot. Dark brown color. Light tan head. Scent is a little boozy and sweet. Taste is molasses, booze and caramel. Good beer.

On draught at Saraveza during Luncheon with the Lion for the final day of PDX Beer Week. Deep dark brown color. Aroma is sticky toffee, molasses, roasted malt, banana and maple. Taste is prune, banana bread pudding, molasses, maple, and dark cocoa nibs. Quite sweet with many dimensions of flavor. Great for a long session of sipping.

Vintage 2014

Pours a dark mahogany brown with some mixed fine tans and a rim of the same - pretty unimpressive appearance. Smells of aritificial cherry flavor, then some booze and oak alongside a solid mix of rasins and dates and a bit of cocoa powder. flavor is very sweet like a cherry cola, some bits of alcohol underneath - but mostly cherry cola. Medium on simple syrup bodied with a hesitant carb and semi dry finish.

Bottle thanks to Ontape ! Pours a deep mahogany with two fingers of khaki foam that fizzles out rather quickly. The nose is beautiful with great bourbon influence, rich toffee, sweet vanilla, cola, dark fruit and just pure pleasure ! The palate follows with pure deliciousness that matches the nose with a nice balance of sweetness and booze with the addition of some rustic leather and earthiness that has depth and nuances of vanilla, anise, date, coconut, caramel, kola nut all rounded out with perfect amount of nutty bourbon that lingers. WOW ! More please !

Had on tap at the Grog. $9.00 for the 8 oz. serving. To tulip, it pours a mahogany-tinted beige dark brown with which an off-beige head barely a finger in length stood. Tastes and smells strongly of caramel syrup, pipe tobacco, bourbon oak, powdered cinnamon, DME, pickled pears, and wool. Vanilla, burnt marshmallows, London yeast, and cedar experienced by swallow. Moderately spicy, chewy, and complicated. Good for tastings; not by yourself at a bar. I couldnt drink a full bottle of this all by my lonesome.

750 ml boxed bomber, thanks brenn79. Aroma consists of coconut, caramel, earth. Pours dark brown with red edges with a one finger beige head that falls fairly quick. Taste is sweet and savory, very fine. Fairly low carbonation, syrupy texture, full-bodied. Doesnt seem as complex as other components in the FW Anniversary blends, but its still so good. Delicious liquid candy.

22 oz bottle, shared with Poisoneddwarf- Pours dark ruby red with a thin light tan head that reduces to a collar. Aroma is toasted coconut, barrel, trademark Firestone, cant wait to taste. The taste is similar, toasted coconut, caramel, barrel, massively complex. Great beer, can see why this is a major component of their anniversary beers.
Bourbon aroma, not hot. Cloudy brown, headless. Bourbon, fudge, nougat. Marzipan finish. Chewy, but quaffable. Tasty, but dangerous.

Dark almost opaque brown with reddish edges. Nose is huge vanilla and coconut oakyness, brown sugar, bourbon. Flavor is same plus some light spicy/pepperyness, chocolate, honey, caramelized banana, toffee, and some dates/prunes/figs. Really pleasant amount of heat and fine carbo make for a good mouthfeel.

Fresh samples on draft and in bottles at ChurchKey. Deep grape soda pour, smallish white head. Nose and flavor are gorgeous, with huge grape, plum, black cherry, vanilla, sweet almond, and cream soda character. Barrel character is beautifully integrated, Its a bit sweet and theres definitely some heat on it, but its so masterfully done and tasty. Cant knock it.

Draught @ Pine Box, Seattle, WA 

Pours dark brown, almost black with a light brown head. Massive heavy and complex aroma of ripe fruits, wood, oak, vanilla, roastiness, licorice, sweet syrup and plums. Taste is heavy, sweet and syrupy with loads of ripe fruits, plums, wood, oak and vanilla. Finish is sweet, complex and woody with some oak, vanilla, plums and syrup. Quite massive and heavy stuff.

On tap at the Pine Box. Brown pour with an off white head. Big cola and sweet caramel aromas. Sweet, with massive caramel malt, brown sugar, and mild cow notes. Really tasty with a fantastic mouthfeel. Good body.

Bottle @ the Tin Bucket (shared with goodbyeohio and my friend Will aka Square Mile who purchased this bottle)... Poured dark brown, opaque, mahogany with a thin forming, khaki head. Aroma contained amazing bourbon barrel character with deep, dark Belgian candied sugars. Tasted like a sublime fortified wine aged in Bourbon barrels. Strong whiskey notes with oak, dark sugars and date or prune-like fruits. Sweet, sticky, boozy and intense. This was insanely awesome.

On tap at FW a dark brownish black with a thick tan head.
Aroma molasses ever slight funk so incredible!
Flavor is way over the top smooth. Sweetly dark fruited with incredible richness. Boozy. Balanced. Just beautifully done. Everything I dreamed of in a Belgium Quad.

Bomber from Total Wine in Sacramento, CA. 2014 vintage. Pours dark cola color with a few bubbles. Aroma is sort of stewed dark fruits with dark malts. Full bodied, at least. Flavor is like plums and dates and dark fruits with a little alcohol and smooth, smooth, treacly dark malt. This is not an ASE, IMHO. FW says Quad, undt auch Ich! Damn delicious quad. Finishes with a bit of heat to cut down the malt. Did I say delicious? Understatement.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2014 65cl, Vintage 2014, exclusive American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex brew, sweet/malty/fruity and slightly alcoholic/woody, yet not too heavy, balanced, cloudy, small head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

22 oz. bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with a medium off white head. Aroma of bourbon, dark fruits, vanilla and mild booze. Flavor is very sweet with strong bourbon overtones. Molasses, medium sweetness, medium alcohol burn. Full bodied with prickly carbonation. Finishes with an alcohol burn. Pretty nice big beer here.

Dark brown, medium head, aroma is pretty intense, cinnamon, cloves, molasses. Taste is bright up front, then extremely rich and sweet, with a bitter and boozy aftertaste. Its like an Abbey quad that is coated in a gooey, bourbony gel. Really terrific.

On tap. Pours a dark brown with an off white head and lacing. It has a strong bourbon aroma and the flavor is similar, with bourbon throughout and a malty, sweet finish over a medium-heavy body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Doug. Thanks man! Pours dark amber brownish purple with a small yellowish head that recedes pretty quickly. Aroma of big time bourbon and vanilla, caramel, toffee, figs, other dark fruits. Smells like a BA Old Ale. Flavor is massive bourbon notes with a smooth vanilla finish. Dark fruits behind the booze, some big oaky notes, and lots of brown sugar, molasses, caramel, and toffee. Not much Belgian Quad going on here but I suspect they werent going for that anyway. Big rich mouthfeel with lowish carbonation. Lots of booze but still very smooth with a lingering vanilla and dark fruits on the palate. Mmmmmmm.
Bottle shared with Steve. Pours reddish brown, clear, with a very small tan head. Nose is malt, molasses, oak, fruit. Flavor is very sweet, but with a bitter finish. Full body. Really good.
From a bottle at WOB. Pours clear ruby copper with a fizzy beige head. Smells like booze, nuts, and sweet sugary honey. Tastes like sweet honey, booze, sugar, dough, warming alcohol.
Bottle shared by some nice folks. Pours a dark brown with minimal off white head. Aroma of booze and dark fruits with some caramel. Taste definitely brings some booze, oak, and dark fruits.

Bottle shared by brewer at WoB. Pours clear tawny brown with caramel highlights. Aroma is bready and caramel malts, booze, berries, dates, light toast, and sugary sweetness. Flavor is chewy malt base, faint bitterness, and heavy booze, dark fruit sweetness, and caramel; semisweet finish. Full body and medium carbonation.

2014 - Bottle Fairly thin dark brown pour with thin off white head. Nose of booze, vanilla, brown sugar, dark fruit, and barrel. Taste follows the nose with an increased sweetness as it warms. Slightly thin (even for a quad). 1-2 years in the cellar will likely improve this beer even more but I wouldnt go much longer given my experience with longer periods of aging of their BA beers.

Aroma of sugared cotton candy, sticky molasses, hinted roasted malts, cough syrup, toffee, malted barley, faint cocoa nibs. Appearance is a beautiful deep amber with a crimson tint and no foam whatsoever, no lacing at all. Taste is sticky melted candy, melted caramel, melted molasses upfront. Immediately followed by slick toffee, barrel wood, sawdust, oily resin, root beer, sugary caramel, and oak notes. Finish is relatively boozey with honey and more sticky malts resigning on the palate. Overall, I am so glad they decided to bottle this for more people to experience this. This is a sticky, malty, syrupy, super sweet treat. I love this. A+ rating.

6 oz pour. At taphouse. Real good aroma, sweet. Malty. Molasses, candied sugar. Some green Apple. Berry. Dark orangy brown color. No head or lace. Sweet flavor. Thick body oily creamy mouthfeel. Sweet drying finish. Very nice. So sweet and malty. Wonderful to sniff. Just add good to taste. Winner. Winner.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Muddy brown with a cream head. Sweet wood, vanilla, rich malts, toffee, leather, and light alcohol. Great palate, sticky malts, chocolate, caramel, toffee, and sticky.

P: Well, its pretty much just black with a very thin an head. S: Its huge, molasses, brown sugar, candi, oak, bourbon, and just a hint of alcohol. T: Full of candy notes, and sugar (this beer is puckery sweet), some caramel comes through along with some oak, a bit of bourbon and a bit of dark fruit. M: Medium body with soft carbonation. O: Nothing more but another BA beer from Firestone. A very balance beer that is never in full force with bourbon but gave me enough to keep me happy.

22oz bomber (2014) shared by Dan P. Pours a dark amber/brown color with a small creamy tan head. Aroma of alcohol, bourbon, barrel, sweet dark fruit, butterscotch, and caramel maltiness. Taste of dry oak, strong bourbon, dark fruit, caramel, and warming alcohol.

Clear dark molasses-y brown with no head. Big sticky nose of brown sugar and rich figs and plums. Rich and sticky. Big rich flavor as well with a load of dark caramel, oak, vanilla char, a light bit of cocoa and brown sugar, rich plums and raisins...just superb.

Pours black in color with notes of plum... Head immediately dissipates, pours a thick viscous consistency... Aroma is amazing, huge vanilla notes, bourbon, caramel... Flavor is more of the same, vanilla and caramel up front, notes of dark fruits, bourbon, oak, tobacco... Heat on the finish, will be even better in a year... Amazingly good beer, not a lot of flaws

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22oz bottle from abv 
Clear dark mahogany with a small tan head, no lacing. Aroma of bourbon, brown sugar and dark malts. Flavors of bourbon, vanilla, sugar and dark fruit 
Very nice

Bottle: &nbsp Deep brown, heavy ruby highlights, spotty lacing, sudsy head. &nbsp Boozy nose, some bourbon, heavy raisin. &nbsp Some vanilla, toasted coconut, and graham cracker on the tongue. &nbsp Sweet, a bit stickee... get it, stickee. &nbsp Big brown sugar finish. &nbsp Not as complex as other quads, no mustiness, basement, dark pitted fruit. &nbsp It instead seems to have a lot of sugary sweetness, loads of brown sugar, with some raisins and soft bourbon notes. &nbsp Decent, but a little rough. &nbsp Not as smooth as their other examples.
Pours a medium dark brown. Notes of toffee, vanilla coffee and bannana. Somewhat cloying

Bottle, just released. Dark brown. Aroma is lots of bourbon and booze. Taste is bourbon, dark fruit, caramel, lots of candy sweetness. Doesnt have a any of the banana yeasty flavors you would expect from a quad, which is a plus in my book.

Bomber from ABV Taproom. Pours a dark brown color with a medium brown head. A super sweet malty nose, huge bourbon. The flavor is more super sweet fruit, toasted malts, huge vanilla bourbon flavors, it mellows, but very hot and just a massive barrel. Quad? Hmmm. Frankly more of a Bourbon Barley Wine. Maybe some dry Belgian yeast. Quite good. Decadent. Dark chocolates in there.

Darkish brown with a good beige head. Aroma is brown sugar, cooked pineapple, honey, dates, hint of bourbon. Sticky mouthfeel, full bodied, sweet and complex on the palate. Taste is raisins, honey, brown sugar, hint of spice and bourbon. So tasty.

Pour out of 22 oz bottle, dark brownish pour with red on the edges, khaki colored head. Aroma brought notes of lots of oak, vanilla, sticky sugars into some earth, raisin, plum, hints of spice, yeast, hints of slight molasses, slight nutty, hazelnut note in there as well. Taste is a mix of dark cocoa, dark fruit, raisin, hints of plum, lots of bourbon, oak, hints of wood, finishing fairly bitter, dry, slightly oaky. Nice.
pour at home thanks to arminjewell. pours a dark reddish brown. aroma is vanilla, coconut, some chocolate, dark fruits. flavor is coconut, bourbon, some chocolate. sick beer

Bottle with friends, thanks to arminjewell for sharing. Pours a deep orangish brown appearance with a thin tan head. Thick brown sugar, caramel, toffee, rich bourbon, coconut aroma. Flavor is fairly sweet but not over the top. German chocolate cake flavor. Caramel, coconut, and a bit of chocolate. Really reminds me of the most recent anniversary beer.

10 ounce draft pour (2014) at Frisco Taphouse in a goblet. Pours dark brown/ruby with light tan head. Aromas of bourbon, dark fruit, caramel. Tasting notes of bourbon, dark fruit, caramel, coconut, toffee, maybe a little red wine. Medium-full body with a dry and warm finish. Medium carbonation. Barrel character is fantastic.

22 oz bottle, 2014 vintage. Thanks Andy Skaggs for bringing this over! Pours a clear deep copper with medium sized tan head that faded to thick lacing. Aroma is Belgian yeast, booze, oak and vanilla, molasses and dark fruits, especially plum. Flavor is akin to a classic Belgian quadrupel profile, but more aggressive due to the alcohol, which is very prominent. Full body with carbonation more active that I would expect in a "Central Coast Quad." I wonder how this would taste in a year or two; too boozy overall for me to enjoy fresh.

Pours dark for a quad. Nice quad nose. Sweet initial taste though may mellow out after cellaring. 

While there are better quads out there this good be fantastic with a tweak or two and/or more time. 

--- RATED

On tap at Backcountry Pizza. Pours a dark brown with small beige head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is brown sugar, oak, and toffee. Medium mouthfeel with strong candy sugar, oak, and leather. Very good.

On tap at the Hungry Monk. Incredible aroma of sweet and hot bourbon, brown sugar, caramel, toffee, heavy oak tannins, vanilla beans, and a hint of dark cherries. Pours a very dark murky caramel. The initial taste is very sweet and boozy, with turbinado sugar, vanilla, sweet caramel, light nougat, hot bourbon, and a slight sour oak tone. Heavy body with a sticky texture and oddly slightly sweet and sour finish. Amazing stuff; so glad I finally got to try it.

Pours up at AZ Strong Ale Fest 2014 with a murky brackish dark darkness that has a mahogany hue to it and supporting a nice looking tan head of foam. The aroma is thick and sticky with lots of pine hops, some thick black licorice-sort-of-black strap molasses, brown sugar and thick maltiness. The taste starts with a good load of thick malt sweetened pine hop stickiness with smooth rivers of sweet bourbon booze. To midway the pine hops get sweet and candy like and happy with richness. Wow! I also get thick floral hops around the edges. Wow.

Sampled @ AZ Strong Beer Fest! Must begin by saying David Walker and Jeff Prior are scholars, gentlemen, and crazy generous human beings! Have always stated that these guys produce the best beer in the country and this one didnt disappoint! Loads of toffee, molasses, brown sugar, toffee, tobacco, vanilla and oak. Complex indeed. An incredible addition to the anniversary series. Sticky and coating but not cloying. Can still feel this on the roof of my mouth and continued to enjoy this minutes later! So
Glad I got a chance to try this!

On tap at Apex on the last day of Stout Fest. Dark hazy mahogany with a ring of beige head. Potent bourbon and fruit, toffee in a cup, vanilla, booze, moderate carbonation and full body, huge bourbon but smooth and sweet, oak, tasty but would only want a taster.

Tap at APEX. Deep brown pour, light brown head. And HOLY HELL this is badass. So rich and decadent. Sweet but not cloying. Toffee, brown sugar, vanilla, rich barrel notes, oak, tobacco. Fucking awesome

Sample at GABF. Glad I waited for this. Classic barleywine with strong malts and low hop profile. Very well balanced though with this bitterness working purely to complement the malt. Strong caramel flavors and dark candy sugar. The oak adds another dimension and tempers the sweetness some. An excellent, deft execution of a style that often leads to beers that overly sweet and syrupy.

On tap at GABF 2013, caramel malty aroma, creamy taste of caramel and some dark fruit.

Draught @ Firestone Walker Barrelworks, Buellton, CA
Pours slightly hazy brown with a small off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, vanilla, oak, dried fruits and alcohol. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and medium bitter with a long warm, boozy, caramel, vanilla and oalk finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

On tap at The Barrelworks. Pours amber with an off white head . Aroma of malt, caramel, some bread, alcohol and bourbon. Flavor is sweet an malty with some warming alcohol, caramel, grains and vanilla. Full body, soft carbonation.

On tap at Firestone Walker Barrelworks. It pours a dark brown body and a small, beige head. A bit alcoholic on the nose, with dried fruits and some bourbon. Chocolate notes too. The flavor is sweet and with a solid dose of dried fruits and chocolate. Decent bitterness too, and alcohol. Full body, soft carbonation. Lasting finish. Overall, too warming, but sure lovely. 130809

26 July 2013, tap at Firestone Walker Barrelworks in Buelton, CA. Brown and clear, nose is tobacco, vanilla, ovaltine. Full body and mildly fizzy. Vanilla, milk chocolate, malt balls, sweet, moderate alcohol. Great! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Snifter at the brewery tasting room. 
Pours reddish brown with tan head and thin lacing. Aroma is malty with notes of molasses, oaky booze, cigar shop, and a hint of the tropics. Taste is quite sweet but with a very pleasing bitter, leathery aftertaste. Full bodied, lively carbonation. Excellent brew, but I like Sucaba a little more.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(Draught) deep copper, fine tan bubbles. Nose of brown sugar, barrel, raisin, vanilla, bourbon, rich. Taste is huge on bourbon, vanilla, barrel, brown sugar, quite toasty and very alcoholic. Nice beer though.

Growler to tulip. Finally the last 16 individual component. Aroma of booze, brown sugar, chocolate, figs. Dark brown, opaque, small ring of tan head. Taste: follows nose. Sweet with big chocolate. Lingering roastiness, big hot alcohol burn on the tongue and throat. Extremely thick, viscous mouthfeel. Soft carbonation, full body. Overall: glad to finally get my hands on this. It's a little too rough to come together as a beer on its own, but the imprint it leaves on the anniversary is fantastic.

(Critique chaotique du extreme beer fest 2013): Entre une stout et un barleywine, chocolat liquide, très décadent. La vanille du baril explose mais se fait aussitot rattraper par les tannins, magistral.

Pouring at the Saturday sessions of Extreme Beerfest.  Pours a deep brown with a thin yellowed beige head.  Tons of warm sweet bourbon and vanilla on the nose.  Cocoa, chocolate, warm bourbon.  Long vanilla.  Boozy and big, tasty but huge.  Long wood, chocolate, vanilla.  Lingering alcohol, cocoa and vanilla.

On tap at EBF 3/16/13.
Fruity and sweet with a hint of oak. This is a very well made barleywine that hides its abv like a champ. I went back for seconds.

On tap. Pours with a hazed deep copper to brown hued body with a medium sized tan head. Aromas are deep and boozy, chewy, molasses, rich maple, oak, mild english esters, plums. Flavors are pretty dry for its size, boozy, but no fusel aggressiveness. Barrel character is much different than the nose: spicy, nutty, alcohol, almost some agave. Fuller bodied with livelier carbonation than expected. Lingering tannin.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2014 Draft at Barrelworks. Pours dark brown with a slight tan head. Sweet sugary nose. Taste is really nice, near overpowering sweetness followed by an almost cinnamon spiciness. This stuff should go into a bourbon barrel ASAP to chill out for 2 or 3 years!

Sample FOBAB 12 - Went to this one early as Ive always thought FW does quite well with the extreme ABV beers.  Poured brown with a medium sized head.  Aroma was tons of sweet caramel, bourbon and dark fruits.  Flavor was quite good, albeit somewhat hot - again, very sweet and sticky, dark fruits abounded, some toffee as well.  A bit one-dimensional, but the dimension is not bad at all.  Palate was actually quite smooth compared to what one might expect - minimal carbonation - warms as it goes down.  Good, yet not great...

Enjoyed on tap at FOBAB. Served in my FOBAB taster glass.

A: Pours a semi clear brown color with a tan head forming on the pour. Nice retention on the head, it recedes slowly to a thick ring and leaves nice splotches of lace.

S: Dark fruits, caramel and some light bakers chocolate. The barrel is there faintly with some light bourbon and oak.

T: Light bourbon and some heat up front. Sweet honey, dark fruits and toffee all present. There is a spicy hop flavor as well that seems to creep up and recedes at different spots during each sip. 

M: Medium bodied with a medium carbonation level.

O: I thought this was solid overall. There was a little too much heat from the booze for me even at 12%. The beer did get better as warmed up so Id suggest waiting a touch before consuming given the opportunity.

Serving type: on-tap

Fobab. Pours a hazy amber with hardly any head. Sweet caramel nose with loads of Bourbon. Solid body, low carbonation, sweet caramel, vanilla, Bourbon and some licorice allsorts. Warming alcohol in the finish - not boozy though.
FoBAB 11. Brown red with a thin head. Caramels dark fruits and a touch of hairspray alcohol. Sweet malts with a phenolly booze. Not too good. 7/3/7/3/13

Draft at pine box. Pours an opaque dark brown. Big tangy sweet nose; treacle, molasses, caramel, raisins, and gingerbread. Sticky thick body. Soft carb. All the sweet bits return for the mid palate. Swimming in residual sugars. Long sticky finish. This could be fun in a couple years, though there isnt much hop to fade slowly with time. Itll just get less sweet.

A - Served a cloudy brown-copper color with a little bit of white head. The head fades down pretty quickly leaving behind a touch of lace.

S - Aroma is full of sweet brown sugar and rich caramel malts. There is a touch of Bourbon, vanilla, and some nutty smells as well.

T - Starts off with some sweet rich caramel malts with some brown sugar and some nutty flavors. Through the middle, the Bourbon comes through with some oak and vanilla. The finish is a mix of rich sweet brown sugar and dark fruit with some Bourbon and some booze.

M - Medium-full bodied with very mild carbonation. Feels smooth with a sweet and warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. Very sweet and bold with a nice bourbon mix with the sweet rich caramel and nutty malts.

On tap at Toronado.  Pours a dark reddish amber with a small white head that settles to a ring and leaves a good amount of lacing on the glass.  The aroma is big caramel, some brown sugar, bourbon, vanilla, some plum, and a bit of brandy.  A hint of of alcohol, but not much.  The taste is sweet with caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, plum, and some bourbon.  The finish is warming with a little alcohol apparent.  Big, full bodied beer, but not syrupy.  Low carbonation.

Tasted on draft at FoBAB 2011.  Pours opaque dark amber with an average tan head that leaves a thin collar of lace.  The nose is candied banana, vanilla, toffee, caramel, and brown sugar.  The flavor is more roasted bitter, with burnt brown sugar, toffee, candied banana, creme brulee, and vanilla.  The body is full and oily with average carbonation and a long toffee, bitter burnt sugar, and candied banana finish.

FoBAB 11- This was one of my favorite beers of the day. Pours a ruby red with off white head. Nose and taste are sweet, woody, and malty. Definitely not for those who like their BWs hoppy. If you like them sweet, this one brings a nice blend of wood, caramel, vanilla, and dark sweet fruits and malts. Very well balanced with almost no heat. Its a keeper!

fobab. pours amber off white head. nose caramel booze vanilla, flavors are
boozey phenolic vanilla toffee molasses too sweet and booze.
FoBAB 2011.  Pours cloudy brown with an off white head.  Boozy aroma, dark fruit, sweet malt, vanilla.  Flavor similar.  Okay.

Tap at City Beer in SF.  Ah, the elusive blend component in the anniversary brews.  A great tick.  Clear cocoa brown in color with a small beige head.  The aroma is big and very nice with huge toffee and dark fruit notes - prune, raisin, and fig - with bourbon and brandy.  Oaky toffee on the flavor, mildly sweet with great raisin/dark fruit notes, brown sugar, bourbon, brandy, and vanilla.  Rich and decadent.  Fairly full body with a good level of carbonation.  A top notch barleywine.  They should bottle this!
On tap at City Beer. Pours black with a thin beige head and a treacle aroma. Ther is a hearty chocolate and brown sugar flavor with a nice bourbon trail.

Draft at FoBAB 9. I get why they blend this one. It is lacking in overall composure but offers some good pieces that could fit the puzzle. Pours a ruddy brown with a fluffy head. Nose is boozy. Sharp burnt raisins, ethanol and vanilla. On taste, big caramel notes, burnt almost, more coconut and vanilla, wood tannins. Alcohol is high, between the native barrel  booze and the beer alcohol. Just doesnt seem quite right. Bit thin bodied as well.
draft... not a big fan of this, really shocking that the masters of barrels didnt pull this one off, the brandy dominates the bourbon and this is just a sweet mess sadly

Sampled at Deconstructed event during LA Beer Week, brown in color with a big bourbon taste to it.  Can almost taste the barrel.  Not what I think of when I think barleywine.  Has a real late burn to it at the end.

On tap at Brouwers. Pours deep, dark brown -- almost black -- with a tan head. Brown sugar, apple and grape juice, caramel, and some booze on the nose. Wow is this ever thick. Seriously syrupy. Sticky indeed. Sweet, for sure, and countered entirely by alcohol, not by hops. This is like melting down a few random pieces of candy containing milk chocolate, caramel, marshmallow, and some nuts, and dissolving them in alcohol. Tastes like a candy store. Totally crazy, and definitely too hot -- this one would need to sit for a good long time before it reached the point where you could take a swig without coughing a little. Glad I got to try it, though!

Tap at Opening Gala SF beer week 2011.   Pours a deep dark ruby oily brown almost violet ruby hints.  Aroma is fruity, prune, figs, big caramel molasses, honey toast, mostly clean with some oak barrel- sweet brandy and some woody toasty bourbon alcohol hint.  Flavor is woody, oak, brandy with a  big thick coating of sugared dried fruits, candysugar, molasses, some earthy tones, and a good long lingering finish of slight bourbon wood, and light bitterness.  Good stuff.

6oz Pour @ Toronado, SF< CA. Dark fig, purple looking pour. Rich malts, oak, vanilla dried fruits, bourbon filled the aroma of this monster of a beer. Strong!!! Huge flavor profile of vanilla, booze, bourbon, RICH maltiness, raisins. Quite flavorful & quite powerful. Fuller sticky mouthfeel. 6oz was definately enough. On tap for SF Beer Week 2011

A: The pour is a dark amber color, perhaps leaning towards brown, with a tan head.

S: The usual sweet, sugar notes of a barleywine are here. I get brown sugar, caramel, and toffee, but theres a weird nuttiness to this beer that seems out of place.

T: This tastes like almost like a really creamy nut brittle with extra nuts. Theres a fair amount of alcohol presence as well, a touch of oak, and some good vanilla notes.

M: The body is medium with a nice creaminess and a low to moderate level of carbonation.

D: This was a weird beer. In fact, several of the blending components for FW14 arent all that great, but somehow they make a delicious final product.
Draft at San Diego Strong Ale Fest 2010.  Gold/brown pour, small off-white head. Sweet caramel malt, bourbon, oak, vanilla, fruit, and some bitter hops in the finish for balance.  Very nice.

At San Diego Strong Ale Festival 2010

Appearance: Pours an amber brown with a dense creamy 1/8 inch tan head.

Aroma: Dried dark fruit, caramel, bourbon, coconut.

Taste: Bourbon, fig, apple pie, burnt sugar and apricot. Finishes with hoppy bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied, sticky.

Overall: A really great sipper. Very complex and enjoyable.
Draft at Firestone 14th party. Light brown golden pour with tiny head. Aroma was honey bourbon, brown sugar. Taste was sweet alcohol, bourbon, oak, with slight bitterness. Pretty good.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2012 Draft at the Firestone 14 Release Party. Nose of oaky vanilla and bourbon, light sweetness, caramelized brown sugar and toffee. Hazy brown with a small beige head. Flavor is light bitterness, caramel malt, toffee, and oaky vanilla with a hint of alcohol warmth in the finish. First rating of this brew. 9/4/9/3/17 4.1 11/6/10
FW XVI Release Best of the Fest IMHO Nose has toffee, light chocolate, sweetness, with nice amounts of vanilla and bourbon. Rest will be the same as before.
